meanings.definition: A structure extending alongshore or out from the shore into a body of water, to which boats may be moored.
meanings.sent1: The docks were busy with boats coming and going.
meanings.sent2: The fishermen gathered at the docks early in the morning.
meanings.sent3: The seagulls perched on the docks, waiting for scraps.
meanings.sent4: The docks reached out like welcoming arms to the incoming ships.
meanings.sent5: The sound of waves hitting the docks was soothing.

meanings.definition: A place for the loading, unloading, building, or repairing of ships.
meanings.sent1: The docks bustled with activity as cargo was loaded onto the ships.
meanings.sent2: The workers repaired the hull of the ship at the docks.
meanings.sent3: The captain accidentally dropped his hat into the water near the docks.
meanings.sent4: The docks were a hive of industry, echoing with the sounds of work.
meanings.sent5: The old lighthouse stood guard at the entrance to the docks.

meanings.definition: To remove or trim the tail of an animal.
meanings.sent1: The farmer carefully docks the tails of the sheep to keep them clean.
meanings.sent2: It is important to dock a horse's tail properly to prevent injury.
meanings.sent3: The vet had to dock the tail of the dog after the accident.
meanings.sent4: She decided to dock the cat's tail to avoid any future problems.
meanings.sent5: Docking the tails of animals is a common practice in farming.
